113465 S2468-8231(23)00548-5 10.1016/j.mcat.2023.113465 The Author(s) Fig. 1 TEM images of showing multi-channelled SBA-15 (A), spherical particles of immobilized ligands (B) LH-SBA15, (C) LH-MCM-41 and the immobilized metal complexes (D) Ni-SBA15, (E) Co-SBA15 and (F) Fe-SBA15. Fig 1 Fig. 2 SEM micrographs of ligand LH-SBA15 (A) and the immobilized metal complexes (B) Ni-SBA15, (C) Co-SBA15 and (D) Fe-SBA15. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Plots of the dependence of catalytic activity and selectivity towards C6 oligomers on the amount of catalyst Ni-SBA15 (metal content calculated based on ICP-AES). Ojwach a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Pietermaritzburg Campus, Private Bag X01 Scottsville 3209, South Africa School of Chemistry and Physics University of KwaZulu-Natal Pietermaritzburg Campus Private Bag X01 Scottsville 3209 South Africa aSchool of Chemistry and Physics, University of KwaZulu-Natal, Pietermaritzburg Campus, Private Bag X01 Scottsville 3209, South Africa b Fachbereich Chemie, RPTU Kaiserslautern-Landau, Erwin-Schrödinger-Str. 54, 67663 Kaiserslautern, Germany Fachbereich Chemie RPTU Kaiserslautern-Landau Erwin-Schrödinger-Str. 54 Kaiserslautern 67663 Germany bFachbereich Chemie, RPTU Kaiserslautern-Landau, Erwin-Schrödinger-Str. 54, 67663 Kaiserslautern, Germany ⁎ Corresponding author. Immobilization of the phenol((triethoxysilyl)propylimino) ligand (LH) on SBA15 and MCM41 afforded the ligands LH-SBA15 and LH-MCM41 respectively. The reactions of LH-SBA15 and LH-MCM41 with NiCl2, CoCl2 and FeCl2 salts produced the respective materials [Ni(LH-SBA15)2Cl2], (Ni-SBA15), [Co(LHSBA15)2Cl2], (Co-SBA15), [Fe(LH-SBA15)2Cl2], (Fe-SBA15) and [Ni(LH-MCM41)2Cl2], (Ni-MCM41) in good yields. The functional group determination, morphology, physical and surfaced properties of the materials containing immobilized ligands and complexes were established from FT-IR, TGA, TEM, SEM-EDX, PXRD, ICP-AES, and nitrogen physisorption measurement techniques. Activation of the complexes on the surface with EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst formed active catalysts for the oligomerization of ethylene affording mainly C6 oligomers. The SBA-15 immobilized catalysts were more active than the corresponding MCM-41 materials, while Ni(II) catalysts performed better than the corresponding Co(II) and Fe(II) systems. The immobilized catalysts could be used in three cycles without significant loss of catalytic activity and selectivity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Metal catalysts Immobilization Silica Ethylene oligomerization Recycling Data availability The data is provided as supplementary material in the manuscript Introduction The production of higher olefins is one of the most studied catalytic processes both in academia and industry, owing to its vital contributions in the petrochemical industries [1]. These higher olefins have a wide range of domestic and industrial applications of higher ethylene oligomers as in lubricants, surfactants, solvents and detergents [2]. Over the past decades, the evolution of transition metal-based homogeneous catalysts in these ethylene oligomerization reactions have witnessed significant growth [3–5]. Despite their high catalytic activities and selectivity, these homogeneous catalysts suffer some drawbacks, mainly associated with the difficulty in separation of the catalysts from products [6]. On the other hand, while the use of heterogeneous systems circumvents the separation dilemma, they also have limitations such as poor selectivity [7]. As a result, the design and development of separable and selective catalysts for various organic transformations represents an attractive research focus [8–11]. Several approaches have so far been adopted to design both single-site and separable catalysts [11]. One such technique is the immobilization of homogeneous catalysts on inorganic supports such as zeolites [12], silica [13] and organic polymers [14,15]. amongst these techniques, the use of silica-based supports has several advantages such as enhanced thermal and chemical stability, large surface areas and a higher density of the active sites, leading to enhanced catalytic performance [16]. It is noteworthy to mention that while a number of immobilized catalysts have been designed for various reactions such as Heck-coupling [17], hydrogenation [18], oxidation [19], their development in ethylene oligomerization is still at its infancy. An illustration is the contribution from Kumar et al. [20]., using MCM-41 immobilized Ni(II) and Pd(II) complexes in ethylene oligomerization reactions. Activation of these immobilized complexes with EtAlCl2 as the co-catalyst form active and recyclable catalysts to give mainly butenes [20]. In another example, Rossetto et al. [21] reported that β-diimine nickel(II) complexes immobilized on SBA-15 oligomerize ethylene with high turn-over frequency (TOFs) of up to 7.2 × 103 h − 1 and selectivity of 98% towards the C4 oligomers. These catalysts are reusable in three successive cycles with marginal loss in catalytic activities and selectivity. It is generally known that immobilized catalysts often display lower catalytic activities when compared to their homogeneous analogues [22]. On a more positive note, the recent report by Tuskaev et al. [23] on nickel(II) complexes anchored on tripodal N^N^N ligands show that the immobilized complexes display higher catalytic activities of 120 kg mol−1 h−1 atm−1 with selectivity of 92% towards 1-butene, while the homogeneous counterparts display catalytic activities of 62 kg mol−1 h−1 atm−1. Over the past decade, our research has largely focused on the design and development of homogeneous and supported catalysts for ethylene oligomerization reactions [24–27]. Encouraged by our recent findings using N^O coordinated metal catalysts immobilized on inorganic supports in ethylene oligomerization reactions [28,29], we herein report the ethylene oligomerization reactions catalysed by N^O coordinated Ni(II), Co(II) and Fe(II) complexes immobilized on silica supports. The effect of the nature of silica support, using MCM-41 and SBA-15, in regulating the physical properties of the complexes and their resultant catalytic performance have been studied. Recycling studies in these ethylene oligomerization reactions and post-catalysts characterization have also be examined in details and are herein discussed. Experimental section General materials and instrumentation All synthetic manipulations were performed using standard Schlenk-line techniques. The solvents were obtained from Merck and dried or distilled using appropriate methods [30]. Ethanol was dried over calcium oxide whilst toluene solvent was treated under sodium/benzophenone reagent, distilled, and stored in 4 Å molecular sieves, while n-heptane was over under calcium hydride, distilled, and stored in 4 Å molecular sieves. Salicylaldehyde (98%), 2′-hydroxyacetophenone (98%), (3-aminopropyl)triethoxysilane (APTES, ≥98%), CoCl2 (97%), FeCl2 (98%), NiCl2 (98%), Santa Barbara Amorphous-15 (SBA-15, 99%) and Mobil Composition of Matter number 41 (MCM-41, 98%) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used as received. 1H NMR and 13C NMR (100 MHz) spectra were recorded on a 400 MHz Bruker Ultra shield NMR spectrometer with CDCl3 and DMSO‑d6 used as the solvents. The infrared spectra were recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrometer 100. A LC Premier micro-mass Spectrometer model LCMS-2020, was used for mass spectral analyses. The ZEISS EVO L 15 scanning electron microscope (conventional SEM, low vacuum, ESEM and EDX) operating at 20 kV accelerating voltage was used to carry out microscopic analyses while energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analyses were carried out using an Oxford make EDX detector. Prior to the analysis, the samples were coated with gold using a Q150R series high vacuum Quorum sputter coater (Laughton, UK). A JEOL 1400 transmission electron microscope (brightfield, darkfield, diffraction, EDX) operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV was used to perform transmission electron microscopic analyses. Elemental composition was performed using a Varian 720-ES inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) device equipped with the ICP Expert II software. Nitrogen physisorption measurements were performed on BELSORP MAX from Microtrac Retzsch. Data evaluation according to Brunauer, Emmett, Teller (BET) and Barrett, Joyner, Halenda (BJH) was carried out with the software BELmaster version 7.3.2.0. The samples were activated in vacuum for 20 h at 130 °C prior to the measurements. Thermogravimetric analyses were acquired on a Perkin-Elmer TGA 4000 instrument equipped with Pyris software at 50- 900 °C with 10 °C/min heating rate. A Varian CP-3800 gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a CP-Sil 5 CB (30 m x 0.2 mm x 0.25 µm) capillary column was used for GC analyses (GC conditions: starting temperature 40 °C for 5 min, the heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 250 °C), while GC–MS analyses were performed on a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010SE. Synthesis of silica-immobilized ligands and their Ni(II), Fe(II) and Co(II) complexes Synthesis of LH-SBA15 The immobilized ligand LH-SBA15, was prepared by adding SBA-15 (1.01 g) to a solution of ((triethoxysilyl)propylimino)phenol LH (0.12 g) [28] in toluene (20 mL) in a 100 mL round-bottomed flask. The slurry was then sonicated for 15 min at room temperature and then refluxed for a further 14 h. At the end of the reaction time, the mixture was filtered, and the crude product washed with toluene (3 × 20 mL) and dichloromethane (3 × 10 mL). The residue was then dried under vacuum at room temperature for 10 h to afford the immobilized ligand as a yellow solid. Yield: 0.95 g, 84%. FT-IR (cm−1): ν(OH): 2305; ν(C=N):1641; ν(Si-O): 1053. Synthesis of LH-MCM41 The MCM-41 immobilized ligand was synthesized in a similar manner as described for LH@SBA-15 using MCM-41 (1.01 g) and LH (0.10 g). Light yellow solid. Yield: 1.05 g (95%). FT-IR (cm−1): ν(OH): 2107; ν(C=N): 1636; ν(Si-O): 1058. Syntheses of [Ni(LH-SBA15)2Cl2] (Ni-SBA15) The nickel(II) material Ni-SBA15 was synthesized by introducing the immobilized ligand LH-SBA15 (0.11 g) to a suspension of NiCl2 (0.07 g, 0.50 mmol) in ethanol (20 mL). The resultant yellow mixture was refluxed for 24 h. After this period, the mixture was cooled, filtered and the residue was dried in an oven at 100 °C for 1 h to furnish a light-yellow powder. Yield: 0.07 g (39%). FT-IR (cm−1): ν(OH): 2240; ν(CO): 1744; ν(C = N): 1635; ν(Si-O): 1055. The materials Co-SBA15, Fe-SBA15 and Ni-MCM41 were synthesized following the protocol described for Ni-SBA15. [Co(LH-SBA15)2Cl2], (Co-SBA15) LH-SBA15 (0.10 g) and CoCl2 (0.05 g, 0.50 mmol). Light blue powder. Yield: 0.06 g (40%). FT-IR (cm−1): ν(OH): 2114; ν(C=N): 1623; ν(Si-O): 1058. [Fe(LH-SBA15)2Cl2], (Fe-SBA15) LH@SBA-15 (0.12 g) and FeCl2 (0.07 g, 0.50 mmol). Brown powder. Yield: 0.08 g (42%). FT-IR (cm−1): ν(OH): 2324; ν(CO): 1740; ν(C=N): 1616; ν(Si-O): 1049. [Ni(LH-MCM41)2Cl2], (Ni-MCM41) Ligand LH-MCM41 (0.11 g) and NiCl2 (0.07 g, 0.50 mmol). Cream white powder. Yield: 0.06 g (33%). FT-IR (cm−1): ν(OH): 3422, 2295, 2226, 2120; ν(C=N):1630; ν(Si-O): 1051. Ethylene oligomerization catalysis Typical procedure for ethylene oligomerization reactions The ethylene oligomerization experiments were carried out in a stainless-steel Parr reactor fitted with a 100 mL glass chamber and a magnetic stirrer bar. A pre-weighed amount of the immobilized complex (10 µmol) was transferred into a dry Schlenk tube under nitrogen atmosphere and n-heptane (30 mL) was added using a syringe. In a typical experiment, 10.30 mg of Ni-SBA15 (equivalent to 0.01 mmol of Ni based on ICP-AES analyses) was weighed and ethylaluminum dichloride co-catalyst, EtAlCl2 (2.00 mmol) to give an Al/M ratio of 200 which was injected into the Schlenk tube containing the pre-catalyst. The solution was then transferred through a cannula into the nitrogen filled reactor and heated to 30 °C while stirring on a hot plate. The reactor was flashed several times with ethylene gas, the ethylene pressure was set at 10 bar and the reaction initiated by stirring. After 1 h, the reactor was cooled to approximately −10 °C using liquid nitrogen and excess ethylene gas was vented off. The reaction mixture was then quenched by addition of 10% hydrochloric acid (2 mL). A portion of the reaction mixture was sampled in a GC-vial for GC-FID and GC–MS analyses to determine identity and distribution of the products. The mass of the product formed was determined using the calibration curve of the R-factors for the olefin standards versus the number of carbons of the standards [31]. Hexene (0.85), octene (0.74), decene (0.50), dodecene (0.39) and tetradecene (0.327) standards were used to obtain a calibration curve and tetradecane was used as an internal standard. The R-factor for butene was extrapolated as 0.981 from the calibration curve. The catalytic activity (goligomer mol−1 M. h−1) was determined using the percentage metal content in the immobilized complexes as determined from ICP-AES analyses. Catalyst recycling experiments In a typical recycling experiment, the spent catalyst was recovered via centrifugation and the oligomeric products were separated and filtered for analyses. The recovered material was washed with n-heptane and ethanol and reactivated by calcination at 300 °C. The reactivated material catalyst was weighed prior to the subsequent experiment, following the protocol described for the standard ethylene oligomerization reaction described in Section 2.3.1. Results and discussion Syntheses and surface analyses of the immobilized metal complexes The pre-ligand, ((triethoxysilyl)propylimino)phenol (LH) was synthesized following literature procedures [28,32] and characterized using 1H NMR (Fig. S1) and FT-IR (Fig. S2) spectroscopies and mass spectrometry (Fig. S3). The immobilization protocol of LH on SBA-15 and MCM-41 and subsequent treatments of the immobilized ligands LH-SBA15 and LH-MCM41 with NiCl2, FeCl2 or CoCl2 salts to produce the respective immobilized complexes materials Ni-SBA15, Co-SBA15, Fe-SBA15 and Ni-MCM41 is shown in Scheme 1 . The immobilized metal complexes were obtained in low yields of 33%−42%, which may be attributed to the wet impregnation method adopted [33]. The compounds were characterized using a combination of techniques such as FT-IR spectroscopy for functional group analyses, TGA for thermal and stability studies, TEM, SEM-EDX for surface and texture determination, ICP-AES for metal content, and Nitrogen physisorption for surface area analyses. To fully confirm the proposed structures of the immobilized metal complexes in Scheme 1, we synthesized and characterized the homogeneous Ni(II) complex by reactions of ligand LH with the NiCl2 salt to give the complex [Ni(L)2] (ESI). The absence of the νOH signal in the spectrum of complex [Ni(L)2 ] (observed at 3060 cm−1 in the free ligand LH, Fig. S2), points to the deprotonation of the OH proton prior to coordination as depicted in Scheme 1. Mass spectrometry of the homogenous Ni complex displayed a peak at m/z = 720 amu, corresponding to the molecular ion [M+Na] of the species [Ni(L)2] (Mw= 707.5 4 g/mol) (Fig. S4). From the spectral data of the homogeneous Ni(II) complex, it is reasonable to assign the general formulae of [M(L)2] in the immobilized complexes as shown in Scheme 1. The FT-IR spectroscopic data display the imine νCN peaks of the free ligand (LH) as a sharp peak at 1612 cm−1 that shift to higher frequencies (1641 and 1636 cm−1) in the immobilized ligands LH-SBA15 and LH-MCM41 respectively (Fig. S5). The formation of the immobilized complexes can be deduced from the observation of these signals at lower stretching frequencies: Ni-SBA15 (νC N = 1635 cm−1), Co-SBA15 (νC N = 1623 cm−1), Fe-SBA15 (νC N = 1616 cm−1) and Ni-MCM41 (νC N = 1630 cm−1), see Figures S5-S8. In addition, the appearance of a strong absorption at around 1049–1058 cm−1 establishes the presence of the Si-O-Si motif in the materials [34]. The thermal stability and decomposition profiles of the immobilized compounds was investigated using TGA (Fig. S9). The materials containing immobilized complexes displayed comparable profiles with weight losses in the regions of 50–100 °C, 150–300 °C, 300–500 °C, and 500–900 °C. For example, the TGA plot of material Fe-SBA15 showed a steep weight loss of 5% between 50 and 100 °C, assigned to the loss of moisture physisorbed on the material's surface (Fig. S9-c). The subsequent weight loss of 2% between 150 and 300 °C corresponds to the chemically adsorbed water molecules and trapped solvent molecules [21]. The decomposition of organic matter could be deduced from the 8% weight loss between 300 °C-500 °C. There was no significant influence of the nature of silica support on the thermal stability of the materials as comparable decomposition profiles were obtained as shown in Fig. S9. On the other hand, it appears that MCM-41 and SBA-15 supports influenced the incorporation of organic matter in the materials as evidenced from the variations in the overall weight losses of 11% in Ni-MCM41 and 14% in Ni-SBA15 [35]. The morphology, texture and elemental compositions of the compounds were elucidated using TEM and SEM-EDX microscopic techniques. The TEM images of the compounds (Fig. 1 ), it was evident that upon immobilization of the ligands and complexes, the structure of the SBA-15 solid support was distorted to form spherical particles with different sizes due to the Ostwald ripening process [36]. The SEM images of SBA15 immobilized materials (Fig. 2 ), revealed no major changes on the morphology of the material upon immobilization of the ligand and complexes. The EDX spectra of the materials (Fig. S10 and Table 1 ) revealed the presence of Si, C, O and Cl and the respective metal cations. From Table 1, Fe-SBA15 exhibits the highest Fe metal content of 7.35%, while Ni-SBA15 shows the lowest Ni metal atom of 0.58% (Table 1, entries 1–3). The ICP-AES studies were done to further authenticate the metal contents obtained from EDX analyses (Table 1). Notably, there was a good agreement between the EDX and ICP-AES results. Interestingly, comparison of metal contents based on the nature of the support showed material Ni-MCM41 to contain higher Ni(II) content of 163.60 µmol/g in comparison to its analogous Ni-SBA15 of 100.53 µmol/g (Table 1, entry 1 vs 4). Similar trends have been reported by Rossetto et al. using β-diimine Ni(II) complexes, where MCM-41 and SBA-15 supports display Ni metal contents of 130±1.87 µmol/g and 127.4 ± 0.39 µmol/g respectively [21,37]. The crystallinity of the materials was determined using PXRD. The diffractogram of the Ni-SBA15 (Fig. S11) showed Miller indices: d100, d110, d200, which are typical for a 2D hexagonal lattice. The same peaks were observed for other materials that were synthesized based on SBA-15 and MCM-41 [40]. Lower intensities observed for 110 and 200 reflections may be attributed to the anchoring of the organic motifs and the addition of the metal centre to the matrix. Nevertheless, the presence of d100, d110 and d200 reflection indices was an indication that the matrix was not severely distorted upon the formation of the respective materials [41]. The immobilized metal complexes and the pure SBA15 and MCM41 supports were also analysed using nitrogen physisorption measurements. Specific surface areas were determined according to Brunauer, Emmett, Teller (BET) and other pore characteristics such as pore size distribution and pore volumes were obtained using the Barrett, Joyner, Halenda (BJH) method or by applying a t-plot analysis. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the synthesized immobilized complexes and their respective pure support materials SBA15 and MCM41 are shown in Fig. S12, while the pore-size distributions (according to BJH) are given in Fig. S13. The surface area and pore size parameters are given in Table 1. From the data, it was evident that both the nature of the support and metal atom controlled the surfaces areas and pore sizes of the materials. In general, the immobilized materials exhibited mesoporous behaviour with average pore diameters of between 5.49 nm to 7.74 nm, which are much higher than their respective pure solid supports. For example, the average pore diameter of SBA15 increased from 3.49 nm to 7.19 nm in Ni-SBA15 (Table 1, entries 1 and 5). This contrasts the relative specific areas of the pure supports, which reduced by approximately 70% upon incorporation of the metal complexes. For instance, the specific surface areas of SBA15 and MCM41 decreased from 870 m2/g and 970 m2/g to 205 m2/g and 220 m2/g in the respective immobilized complexes Ni-SBA15 and Ni-MCM41 (Table 2 , entries 1, 4–6), and is consistent with appreciable incorporation of the metal complexes on the support matrix. With respect to the identity of the metal atom, the Co(II) and Fe(II) materials Co-SBA15 and Fe-SBA15 show the least and highest surface areas of 190 m2/g and 260 m2/g respectively (Table 1, entries 2 and 3), consistent with previous findings [38]. The influence of the nature of support in regulating the surface area of the materials could also be derived from the relatively higher surface area of 220 m2/g for the Ni-MCM41, in comparison to the value of 205 m2/g reported for the Ni-SBA15 complex (Table 1, entries 1 and 4). Expectedly, the material Ni-MCM41 displayed smaller average pore diameter of 5.49 nm than the analogous material Ni-SBA15 of 7.19 nm [39]. From the pore distribution of the materials, it is evident that compound NiMCM41 displays wider pore distributions, compared to the analogous NiSBA15 compound (Figs. S13a and S13d), consistent with literature findings [39]. Ethylene oligomerization reactions catalysed by immobilized catalysts Preliminary and optimization studies of the ethylene oligomerization reactions The immobilized metal complexes Ni-SBA15, Co-SBA15, Fe-SBA15 and Ni-MCM41 were screened as catalysts in ethylene oligomerization reactions in n-heptane as the solvent using ethylaluminum dichloride (EtAlCl2) as the co-catalyst (Scheme 2 ). Analyses of the ethylene oligomerization products using GC (Fig. S14) and GC–MS (Fig. S15) confirmed the formation of C6 as the major fraction, C4 oligomers and trace amounts of higher C8 and C10 olefins (Table 2). Initial reactions conditions using Al/M ratio of 200, 10 bar at 30 °C were employed and furnished catalytic activities of up to 35,000 g·mol−1M·h−1 (Table 2). We then investigated the effect of the catalyst loading (metal content based on ICP-AES analyses) on the catalytic performance of Ni-SBA15 by varying the amount of the catalysts from 5 µmol to 20 µmol (Fig. 3 ). Generally, the catalytic activities of Ni-SBA15 decreased with increasing amounts of the catalyst/metal contents. For example, catalytic activities of 37,500 g·mol−1·Ni·h−1 and 18,000 g·mol−1Ni·h−1 were recorded at Ni loadings of 5 µmol and 20 µmol respectively. A plausible explanation for the decline of catalytic activities with higher metal loadings could be that at high metal loadings, agglomeration (reduced catalyst dispersion) is possible, thus limiting access of the monomer to the active sites [42]. This is also supported by the data in Fig. S16, which shows a decline in the catalytic activity of the materials with increasing metal contents. Interestingly, the selectivity of the catalysts was also influenced by the metal concentrations (Fig. 3). For example, the selectivity for C6 increased from 69% to 80% as the metal loading of Ni-SBA15 was increased from 5 µmol to 20 µmol respectively (Fig. 3). While this phenomenon has been reported before [43] its exact interpretation is not quite clear to us at this moment. Influence of nature of support and metal atom in the ethylene oligomerization reactions The main objective of this contribution was to examine the effect of the silica support and metal atom on the catalytic performance of the immobilized complexes using SBA-15 and MCM-41 as templates (Table 2). From the results, immobilization on SBA-15 support afforded more active Ni catalyst than the use of MCM-41. For example, Ni-SBA15 and Ni-MCM41 displayed catalytic activities of 35,000 g·mol−1Ni·h−1 and 31,000 g·mol−1Ni.h−1 respectively (Table 2, entries 1 vs 4 and Fig. S17). This observation may be assigned to the generally larger pore size of SBA-15 compared to MCM-41, which facilitates efficient inter-channel transportation of ethylene within the pores of the materials resulting in enhanced oligomerization reactions [44]. The observed trends are in good agreement with the those of Guo and co-workers [45], where the Fe-SBA15 catalyst (1.75 × 106 g·mol−1Fe·h) shows higher catalytic activities than the corresponding Fe-MCM41 (1.45 × 106 g·mol−1Fe·h) system. In addition, the plot of the catalytic activity vs the BET surface area of the catalysts (Fig. S18) reveals an inverse relationship. To further understand the role played by the catalyst support, we tested the homogeneous [Ni(L)2] complex and compared its catalytic activity with the analogous NiSBA15 and NiMCM41 systems. From the data, it is interesting to note that the catalytic activity of the homogeneous system was slightly lower (28 000 g·mol−1Ni.h−1) than the respective immobilized NiSBA15 (35,000 g·mol−1Ni.h−1) and NiMCM41 (31,000 g·mol−1Ni.h−1) catalysts (Table 2, entries 1, 4- 5). While immobilized catalysts generally show lower catalytic activities compared to their homogeneous counterparts [20,21,37], instances where they exhibit higher catalytic activities are also known [23]. The nature of the metal atom also controlled the catalytic activities of the materials (Table 2). In general, the Ni(II) materials showed greater catalytic activities compared to the corresponding Fe(II) and Co(II) catalysts (Table 2, entries 1–3). As discussed in the nature of supports, this observation can also be assigned to the combined larger pore volume and diameter of Ni-SBA15 (0.45 cm3/g and 7.19 nm) compared to those of Co-SBA15 (0.42 cm3/g and 7.74 nm) and Fe-SBA15 (0.45 cm3/g and 5.72 nm). From these catalytic trends (general increase in catalytic activity with pore size), it can therefore be conceived that the ethylene oligomerization reactions occur within the pores of the materials (diffuse controlled) rather than on the surface of the material due to adsorption [46,47]. In terms of product distribution and selectivity, there was also good correlations between the pore sizes of the catalysts and product distribution. For example, selectivity towards the major C6 oligomers of 71% and 80% were obtained for catalyst Ni-SBA15 (0.45 cm3/g) and Ni-MCM41 (0.38 cm3/g) respectively (Table 2, entries 1 and 4). This suggests that the smaller pore volume of Ni-MCM41 favours retention of the preformed C4 oligomers resulting in chain propagation to form more C6 oligomers. The identity of the metal atom also influenced product distribution. For example, Ni-SBA15 catalyst produced lower amounts of C6 oligomers (71%) in comparison to 84% and 92% afforded by the analogous Co-SBA15 and Fe-SBA15 respectively (Table 2, entries 1–3). This trend is in tandem with those of homogeneous behaviour where Ni(II) catalysts are known to favour dimerization of ethylene while Co(II) and Fe(II) systems promote trimerization reactions [48–50]. Another explanation, which agrees with the observed catalytic activity trends is that smaller pore size favour retention of C4 fractions and promotes ethylene reincorporation to give more C6 oligomers. This argument is well supported by the highest composition of C6 oligomers (92%) produced by Fe-SBA15 catalyst, which has the smallest pore size (5.72 nm) in this series (Table 2, entries 1–3). More importantly, the selectivity of the immobilized systems was comparable to the homogeneous catalysts. For example, percentage compositions for C6 of 80% and 85% were recorded for NiMC41 and [Ni(L)2] respectively ((Table 2, entries 4 and 5) Catalyst recycling and post characterization studies The recyclability of the immobilized catalysts in ethylene oligomerization reactions was conducted in three successive runs as shown in Table 3 and Fig. 4 . After the first run (cycle), a fresh EtAlCl2 co-catalyst (2 mL, 200 equivalence) was added to the recovered and reactivated materials. The data confirm that these immobilized metal complexes are recyclable in ethylene oligomerization reactions, albeit with some reductions in catalytic activities, depending on the nature of the support (Fig. 4). For example, catalyst Ni-SBA15 showed the highest stability and recycling efficiency, displaying catalytic activities of 35,000 g·mol−1Ni·h−1 and 30,000 g·mol−1Ni·h−1 (translating to a 15% drop) in the first and third runs respectively (Table 3, entry 1), in contrasts to significant reduction in catalytic activity of 25% recorded for the corresponding Ni-MCM41 (Table 3, entries 1 vs 4). Similarly, we were able to establish that by changing the metal atom, the recycling efficiency was also altered. This is illustrated by the percentage losses in catalytic activities of 15% and 33% for the Ni-SAB15 and Fe-SBA15 respectively (Table 3, entries 1 vs 3). More significantly, the oligomer distribution and selectivity remained largely unchanged during the recycling experiments in all the catalysts (Table 3 and Table S1). For example, using catalysts Ni-SBA15, compositions of the C6 oligomers of 71% and 70% were obtained in the initial and second cycle experiments respectively (Table 3, entry 1). Our attention then shifted to the understanding of the reasons behind the slight reductions in catalytic activities in the recycling experiments. First, we performed hot filtration experiments to establish any possible leaching of the active species. No quantitative catalytic activity was obtained from the filtrates, signifying minimal/absence of leaching of the active species. ICP-AES analyses of the spent catalysts was then carried out to elucidate any possible loss of the active metal species during catalyst recovery (Table 3). The results confirm the loss of the metal species as witnessed in Ni-SBA15 recording Ni metal contents of 100.53 µmol/g and 73.86 µmol/g (26% loss of the Ni species) in the fresh and spent catalysts (Table 3, entry 1). Similar trends were observed for the other catalysts (Table 3, entries 2–4). There was a good correlation between the losses in metal content and catalytic activities (Fig. S16). For example, catalyst Fe-SBA15, which recorded the greatest loss in metal content of 43%, also witnessed the highest loss in catalytic activity of 33% (Table 3, entry 3). On the other hand, catalyst Ni-SBA15 displayed the lowest reduction in metal contents and catalytic activities of 26% and 15% respectively (Fig. S19). In terms of the nature of support, catalysts Ni-MCM41 recorded the higher reduction in metal content and catalytic activity of 39% and 25% respectively, compared to values of 26% and 15% obtained for Ni-SBA15 (Table 3 , entries 1 and 4). These data suggest that the decrease in catalytic activities of the immobilized materials in the recycling experiments could be assigned to the reduction of the active metal species, with the SBA-15 support imparting greater stability than the MCM-41 support. Finally, we analysed the used materials using TEM to ventilate if any changes in the texture and morphology of the materials could account for the observed reductions in catalytic activities in the recycling experiments (Fig. 5 ). The TEM images of the spent catalyst Ni-SBA15 shows some slightly deformed morphology when compared to the TEM images of the fresh material (Fig. 5). Furthermore, the TEM image of the recovered catalyst revealed the formation of metal nanoparticles as tiny dark spots in the catalyst's structure (Fig. 5 b). Similarly, the white spots in the used catalyst (Fig. 5 B) may be associated with the decomposition of EtAlCl2 co-catalyst to form alumina ash. From the TEM images, it is therefore possible that the damages and changes in the catalyst structure may also be responsible for the observed reductions catalytic activities in the recycling experiments. Comparison of current immobilized catalysts with reported systems Finally, we carried out a comparative analyses of the performance of the current immobilized catalysts with other immobilized systems present in literature in the ethylene oligomerization/polymerization reactions (Table 4 ). In general, our catalysts showed comparable behaviour to the reported systems. Interestingly, the beta-diimine Ni(II) systems reported by Rossetto et al. [21,37] afford C4 oligomers as the major products, in sharp contrast to our catalysts, which gave C6 as the major products (Table 4 , entries 1–2, 6–7), indicating that product distribution is largely controlled by the nature of the coordinated ligands. This is supported by the findings of Kumar et al. [20] using Davisil supported (pyridyl)imine Ni(II) catalysts, which are more active than our current catalysts (TOF of 239 000 g·mol−1·h−1) but has poor selectivity, giving mainly alkyltoluenes (Table 4 , entry 4). Comparison of the current silica immobilized catalysts with our recently reported Fe3O4 immobilized systems [28], reveal that the silica supports (MCM-41 and SBA-15) impart higher catalytic activity compared to the Fe3O4 support. For example, catalytic activities of 10,500 g·mol−1·h−1, 35,000 g·mol−1·h−1 and 31,000 g·mol−1·h−1 are displayed by Ni2@Fe3O4, Ni-SBA15 and Ni-MCM41 respectively (Table 4, entries 5–7). Nevertheless, both the current silica immobilized catalysts and the previously reported Fe3O4 immobilized systems [28] predominantly produce hexene oligomers. As shown in Table 4, entry 3, immobilization of the famous Gibson bis(imino)pyridine Fe(II) catalysts on SBA15 support produces mainly polyethylene [51], but show lower catalytic activities than our current silica immobilized systems. Conclusions The SBA-15 and MCM-41 immobilized Ni(II), Co(II) and Fe(II) complexes have been synthesized and characterized using FT-IR, TGA, XRD, TEM, SEM-EDX, ICP-AES, and BET analyses. Both the nature of the support and metal atom influence the physical properties of the materials. In general, the SBA-15 immobilized systems exhibit large pore sizes and lower surface areas compared to the MCM-41 supported catalysts. Activation of the immobilized complexes with EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst afford active catalysts in ethylene oligomerization reactions to give predominantly C6 oligomers. The physical properties of the materials influenced both their catalytic activities and selectivity in the ethylene oligomerization reactions. The higher catalytic activities and lower fractions of the C6 oligomer fractions of the SBA-15 immobilized catalysts confirm that the reactions occur within the pores of the materials rather than on the surface. The immobilized complexes were used in three consecutive cycles with minimum reductions in catalytic activities and selectivity. The SBA-15 support imparted better stability and recycling efficiencies of the catalysts. Losses in active metal atom and structural changes to the materials may be implicated in the reductions in catalytic activities in the recycling experiments. coredata.dc:description: Immobilization of the phenol((triethoxysilyl)propylimino) ligand (LH) on SBA15 and MCM41 afforded the ligands LH-SBA15 and LH-MCM41 respectively. The reactions of LH-SBA15 and LH-MCM41 with NiCl2, CoCl2 and FeCl2 salts produced the respective materials [Ni(LH-SBA15)2Cl2], (Ni-SBA15), [Co(LHSBA15)2Cl2], (Co-SBA15), [Fe(LH-SBA15)2Cl2], (Fe-SBA15) and [Ni(LH-MCM41)2Cl2], (Ni-MCM41) in good yields. The functional group determination, morphology, physical and surfaced properties of the materials containing immobilized ligands and complexes were established from FT-IR, TGA, TEM, SEM-EDX, PXRD, ICP-AES, and nitrogen physisorption measurement techniques. Activation of the complexes on the surface with EtAlCl2 as co-catalyst formed active catalysts for the oligomerization of ethylene affording mainly C6 oligomers. The SBA-15 immobilized catalysts were more active than the corresponding MCM-41 materials, while Ni(II) catalysts performed better than the corresponding Co(II) and Fe(II) systems. The immobilized catalysts could be used in three cycles without significant loss of catalytic activity and selectivity.
